div.p: See likewiſe in Crollius Baſil. Chym. p. 267. alſo Hartman in Comm. Nichola. Diſpens, and Wecker in Antidot. Special. Lib. 2. p. 981. & 989, 997.999. Munder makes a great reckoning of the Deſcription of Oppodeldoch in his Tractate De Calcantho. c. 7. and out of Sennertus Lib. 5. Pr. p. 414.

Tenthly, in the like Cure of Attraction we ſee that the powder of the Load-ſtone is alſo of great vertue, as the Cure of ruptured folkes can teſtifie.Lib. 7. Chir. c. 15 in Keligraph. cap. 7. For Pareus and out of him Geiger report of a certaine Chyrurgion that had ſo cured Childrens ruptures, that having wrought the Load-ſtone into the fineſt flower, and uſed the ſame in a Pultis of Barley Flower: did afterwards annoynt the Groine wherein the Inteſtine was fallen downe, and aſperged it with the ſmall filings of Iron, the part being bandaged and truſſed up as is fitting, the Curation was thus finiſhed. The efficacy of the Remedy ſaith Geiger ſeemes thereof to depend, that the load ſtone being of ye ſame nature with the Iron aſperged upon the groine out of a deſire to attract, doth with a kind of violent force ioyne to it ſelfe the fleſhy and fatty parcells interiected, which every way clinging together and binding the laxity of the Peritonaeum, yea and in ſucceſſe of time cleaving faſt unto the very ſame doe intercept the way, the Inteſtine or Omentum will ſlip into; which ſeemes no more abhorrent unto reaſon than that we ſee the very Load ſtone doth this and that way diſtract Iron after it through the thicknes of a board that's laid betwixt.Lib. 1 p. 54 Sucickard indeed according to the opinion of others doth after the manner, but the matter ſeemed to come to the ſame effect. Firſt ſaith he, they propine to the infirme the filings of Steele in the beſt old Wine, then outwardly apply to the part affected the load-ſtone which againe conſtraines and ioynes together the broken skins that are ready to fall aſunder, which when 'tis done, they ſpread upon a Plaſter of Dogſ-skin the Root of the great Comfrey contuſed and made into a Poultice, which being laid upon the part affected, they ſay they heale many in the ſpace of eight dayes.

To conclude, laſtly who can deny the experience obſerved in the Pragenſian Swallow-knife, where likewiſe the Magneticall Emplaſter was uſed, and the way ſhewed then where the Section was fitteſt to bee made. In our Ruſtick ſomething not unlike this is obſerved; for upon that place: where a piece of the Magneticall Emplaſter
was layed, there aroſe a little kind of ſwelling, yea the ſicke man then perceived a certaine motion of the knife towards that part. But whence all this? ſooth no otherwiſe then from the vertue of the tractive faculty of the Load-ſtone, and other things likewiſe endowed with an Attractive quality. Who therefore, theſe things well conſidered, could ſay that the pulverized Load-ſtone is nothing worth, and in vaine to be preſcribed for extraction of Iron, and to be mixt in Medicaments?

div.head: The third Section. Of the very Inciſion of the Ventricle, and extraction of the Knife.
div.p:
THe Body being well and rightly fitted with Balſamick oyles and other things neceſſary, at laſt the ninth day of Iuly Stylo noſtro was appointed for the operation. There met therefore with the Deane of the faculty of Phyſicke, the moſt excellent Phyſitians, honourable members of the ſame Colledge, as alſo the Students, Maſters of our Art, together with the moſt experienced Chyrurgion and Cutter of the Stone, Maſter Dan. Schwabius my Goſſip and Venerable friend now in Heaven. When all things therefore were ready at hand as well externall and internall Cordialls, as other Chyrurgicalls, the Divine Asſiſtance and Benediction being firſt invoked, the Ruſticke who with an undanted courage waited the Section, was bound to a wooden Table, and the place being marked out with a Coale, the inciſion was made towards the left ſide of the Hypochondrium ſome two fingers breadth under the ſhort Ribs, according to the direction, and firſt the skin and that fleſhie pannicle
(there was no fat ſeene) and then the ſubiected Muſcles, as alſo the Peritonaeum was cut and opened. And although the Ventricle did ſomewhat ſinke downe, and avayding our fingers ends did not ſo preſently admit of apprehenſion, and a little ſtaid the Operator and ſtanders by, yet at length attracted and contracted with a ſmall needle crooked, it ſhewed that the knife was there, which being laid hold on, and the poynt brought upwards, the Ventricle above the ſame was a little inciſed, and the knife ſucceſfully extracted, which was viewed by all that were ſtanding by, and greatly applanded both by them and the Patient himſelfe, who profeſſed that this was the very knife he ſome few daies before had ſwallowed, but the wound it ſelfe when the knife was drawne forth was quickly allayed.

div.head: Poſition the 6. That the worth of the Ventricle it is great, the benefit greater, the neceſſity greateſt, yet the wounds thereof not to be reckoned of (if they touch not the upper part of the Orifice) as neither becauſe of the membranous ſubſtance to bee thought mortall in themſelves, yet not voyd of danger.
div.p:
THere are indeed three Spring heads, to wit, the Diſeaſe, the Cauſe, and the Effects from whence doe flow the number of thoſe that are properly called Indicants, the Curatory regarding the Diſeaſe, the Preſervatory which reſpect the Cauſe, and the Vitall, this lookes unto the effects: yet many things there are, which the Phyſitian neceſſarily muſt heed in the conſideration of Diſeaſes, not as the prime Indicants, but the Indicants and Co indicants of the true, as is gathered out of Galen. 11. M. M. c. 13. &. 9. M. M. 3. Amongſt theſe by beſt
right the part affected challengeth to it ſelfe the Chie •
dome, whoſe reaſon and conſideration is eſteemed to be of ſo great moment that by many it hath beene placed among the primary Indicants, for it not onely ſhe weth with the finger as it were the true Indicants, and ſo inveſteth the nature of Signes, but conferreth much to the inſinuation of the things that are to bee done, and their naturall adminiſtration. Moreover it ſuggeſteth the Prognoſticke grounds, and plainely teacheth what iſſue the Diſeaſe may have. In wounds indeed not onely the greatneſſe of the wound and malignity of the cauſe, but the excellency and precellency of the part affected is to bee regarded, whereby ſo we might be able to declare whether the wound thereon inflicted bee deadly, or dangerous, or not deadly. For this excellency hath concomitant hoth utility and necesſity, if now then we ſhall conſider the Ventricle, may not an undoubted Prognoſticke of the wounds thereof hee made? This part it hath the notableſt place of worth, becauſe both ſuggeſting to the whole body the greateſt profit, and is to the ſame exceeding neceſſary. For as man cannot naturally prolong life without meat and drinke, ſo neither can he want the Organ of the ſame appointed for concoction. There are indeed many examples of thoſe that not onely for many daies but moneths too, yea yeares have lived without any meat or drinke, as note Smetius in Miſcellan. p. 551. Lang. Lib. 2. ep. 27. Donat. Lib. 7. Med. Hiſt. mir. cap. 1. & lib. 4. c. 14. Schenk. lib. 3. obſ. med. 39. &c. Ioubert. lib. 1. Parad. 2. Quercitan. Diaetetic. Poly. Hiſt. p. 204. Hildan. Centur. 5. p. 113. Sennertus. lib. 3. Practic. par. 1. S. 1. c. 2. and others. But as theſe are reckoned among the rater things of nature, ſo their life too was very miſerable untill they came againe unto the naturall meanes. Wherefore Nature provided for all Creatures a ſtomack, that the food aſſumed at the mouth, ſhould be by the ſame received, being receiued, diſgeſted, being diſgeſted diſtributed to all the other parts of the body.Lib. 1. Dc prax. med. adm. Obſ. 4. Zacutus Luſitanus notes of a boy often yeares of age, that for 3. yeares lived without a braine. Out of the ſame Zacutus
it is evident, that in a certaine boy that had the conſumption of the lungs, they were not to be found (the Region of the Thorax after his death being diſſected) but onely a kind of mucilage growne to ye Aſpera Arteria: and that in a Girle of three yeares of age, dead of a continuall Quartan Ague, the lungs alſo were ſo waſted that nothing of them appeared but onely the skin full of purulent matter, yet not once having complained ('tis to bee accounted ſtrange) of any Cough, or ever ſpat any filthineſſe.

I have obſerved here at Regiomontium of a Dropſie-woman that was reſtored, made ſhift to rub out for a whole yeare, ſo, as to goe to Church: and to goe about her domeſticke affaires, after that dyed ſuddenly of a Fever. In whoſe Abdomen there was found a little relicke of the Liver, but quite corroded. We read in Schenk that there was nothing found of the Liver and Milt in Matthias Ortelius. Lib. 6. c. 88. & lib. 3. c. 72. Aetius tetrab. 4. Serm. 4. c. 76. Nic. Flor. Ser. 3. Tr. 3. c. 26. Lang. l. 2. Ep. 39. Benivent. de abdit. c. 11. Chriſt. à Vega com. ad • ph. 18. Lib. 8. &c. Paraeus. Lib. De Hom. gen. c. 41. Glandorp. in ſpecul. Chirur. p. 185. Sche. l. 4. Obſ. 303, 304, 305. Zacut. lib. 2. p. 196. It appeareth out of Aegineta &c. that many women have lived, and canlive without a wombe. Moreover Teleſius witneſſeth. Lib. 5. rer. nat. c. 28. and out of him Hildan▪ Cent. 4. Obſ. Chyrurgic. 51. that in one that dyed of a continuall diſeaſe there was not any portion of the heart found, but onely the coate thereof. But that any man ever wanted a Ventricle or ſtomack, as I remember, I never obſerved among Phyſitians, for nature would not have the food offered raw and indigeſted to the parts, but firſt prepared and throughly fitted in the ſtomacke. Hence alſo it is that the health and ſafety of the whole body depends upon the good diſpoſition of the ſtomacke: when this is well all the body is well, but when the ſame is ill affected, a crude and vitious Chyle is ſubminiſtred to the Liver the vitouſneſſe whereof a ſecond coction can no way mend, & ſo alſo after that an impure bloud not without detriment of health is ſupplyed unto every part. This the benefit and necesſity of the Ventricle now long ſince did Agrippa Menen • us declare at the Senate, being a Patrone for the Commonalty of Rome in an elegant Apologue, and concludes that the ſtomacke nouriſhes the body ſo long as it is nouriſhed, and preſerves it ſo long as it is
its ſelfe preſerved, and that it is as it were the common Store-houſe, giving to every one its owne, and conſerving the peace of all,Lib. 6. Antiq. p. 607. as it is in Livie. as alſo Dionys. Halicarnaſius, for which cauſe the ſtomacke too is by Quintus Serenus adorned with a Royall Diadem, while he ſaith,

q.l: Qui ſtomachum Regem totius corporis eſſe
Hujus enim validus firmat tenor omnia membra,
Et contra ejuſdem franguntur cuncta dolore.

div.p:
They that ſtrive for the ſtomacke to be King of the whole body, ſeeme to have good reaſon, for it being ſtrong all the members are confirmed, and on the contrary being ſicke are weakned. But hence muſt all the wounds of the Ventricle be proclaimed deadly? So indeed with Hippocrates have thought Celſus Lib. 5. de re Med. c. 26. Valleriol. Lib. 3. enarr. medic. p. 442. Foreſt. Lib. 6. Obſ. Chirur. 5. Comm. Frambeſſar. Lib. 8. Canon. and conſult. medic. 13. & Tagault. Lib. 1. Inſtit. c, 3. who for three coates affirmes that the wounds thereof are mortall.Lib 6. Aph. 18.
1. Becauſe the part it ſelfe is nervous and bloudleſſe.
2. Becauſe its uſe for converſation of life is perpetually neceſſary and beneficiall.
3. Becauſe medicines cannot to this more inward part be commodiouſly applyed; many doe adde examples:Cent. 1. curat. 67. &c. So Amatus Luſitanus obſerves of a man that dyed of a ſlighter wound, of the Ventricle about the bottome, and other like examples alſo there are may be produced, which ſhew that a man may dye even of the ſlighteſt wounds.

Indeed Galen long ſince ſomewhat doubted of the truth of this generall Rule. For in his Commentaries upon the ſaid Aphoriſme of Hippocrates, he ſaith, In the Ventricle it is doubted (to wit, that the wound is deadly) for they ſay ſome ſometimes have bin wounded there, but ſeldome bealed. And in ſooth the Volumes of Phyſitians witnes; That even the deep wounds of the ſtomacke have beene beſt conſolidated.Lib. 2. Meth. c. 503. Albucaſis writes that hee had cured the
wounds of the Ventricle, and inteſtines. Chriſt. a Vega in his Commentaries to the quoted Aphoriſme, reports of a Chyrurgion that ſwore that he had cured a man who being wounded in the Ventricle not long after he had eaten, did caſt forth the Chyle by the wound.Cap. 12 de Vulnerib. Lib 3. obſ. 122. Cent. Fallopius confeſſeth that hee had cured a man and a woman from whom the meat and the Chyle egreded. Schenke out of the obſervations of Oetheus reports of ſome Chyrurgions, that conſtantly affirmed they had undertaken the cure of a Souldier, a ſtrong and couragious man that by a Ruſtick Hunting-ſtaffe was deeply wounded about the right Hypocondrium, whoſe ſtomacke on the right ſide being perforated reſtored the drinke and broth he had taken by the wound: the ſtanders by in the interim having this Prognoſtick given, diligently adviſed that the wounded part of the ſtomacke brought forth, and the skin ſhould bee faſtened together with one and the ſame future, and ſo after wards the wound being ſucceſfully conſolidated, the Patient recovered his former ſtrength. The Hiſtory of the-Ventricle that was hurt and healed in the Pragenſian Swallow-knife teacheth and confirmes the ſame. Some few yeares agoe (as I received it from credible men) a certaine Marriners man living at Dantzike, a few houres after that he had eaten ſome Herring and raw Cowcumbers, was wounded by another in the ſtomacke, the Chyrurgion was called who ſeeing that the wound was deep, and ſuppoſing the Cure more difficult, for the matter remaining which hee had ſwallowed did artificially extract the ſame, and ſo afterwards ſuccesfully wove out, and finiſhed the Web of this Curation.

Mat • heus writes of a certaine Carter, that after ſupper was wounded by a knife into the Abdomen, but in a moneths time the Ventricle grew together, and the ſicke man was healed. To this experience there are reaſons that doe accord,quaeſt. Medic. 21. for the Ventricle does not a little participate of the fleſhy ſubſtance, lurking among the common membranes therefore by the vertue thereof the concretion and coaleſcence of the wound might be well diſpatched: for
wee ſee even daily that the necke of the Bladder having likewiſe a little carnoſity is healed, when the ſtone is thence extracted.In Chirur. p. 221. For this ſame wound Feliz Wirtz hath the beſt way of cure. Infinite examples teſtifie that the wombe which hath the like ſubſtance with the Ventricle being oftentimes diſſected, hath beene againe very well conſolidated. See Dodonaeus, p. 282. Cornar. conſult. medic. p. 118. Hoch ſteter. Decad. 6. Obſ. 3. in Schol. Franciſe. Rouſſet. tr. de part. Caeſar. & Baubin. in append. eiuſdem tract. Sennert. Lib. 4. Pract. part. 1. S. 2. c. 16. & part. 2. S. 6, c. 8. Then who would deny to the membranous and nervous parts the Balſame wherewith as they may be conſerved, ſo too afterwards may they be united and cured, if nature be firſt helpt with Art. Secondly it facilitates the Cure, becauſe things taken at the mouth, yea and outwardly applyed may more eaſily be inſinuated into the wound.Lib. 9. Chir. c. 51. Hence it is not ill concluded with Paraevo: wounds that pierce the ſubſtance of the Ventricle, the Chyrurgeon ſhall not let them alone as deplorable and remedileſſe, yea nor ſpare labour nor induſtry in the ſedulous Curation of them, for a doubtfull hope is better then a certaine deſperation. But yet if they bee inflicted upon the upper Orifice, they are to be reckoned moſt dangerous, for the Region abounds with Nerves derived a Sextae conjugationis pari, whence ariſe exquiſite ſenſes and more bitter anguiſhes,Hipp. S. 5. aph. 2. Celſ. l. 5. c. 6. yea Convulſions which in wounds are affirmed mortall, as alſo Bilious vomitings more lacerating the wound, theſe are to be feared. And laſt of all the uſe of internall Remedies is not ſo fitting, ſince they when they are taken ſinke unto the bottome.

div.head: Of the Conſolidation of the wound. The 4. Section.
div.p: THe Knife being ſucceſfully brought forth, and the Patient eaſed of his bands, the wound was in that manner as was fitting cleanſed, and the Abdomen that was inciſed, cloſed up with 5. Sutures, but by their interſtices the Balſame was in ••• ed warme, and Tents impregnated with Balſame laid thereon, and then a Cataplaſme of Bole, the white of an • gge, and Allum to avert all inflamation laid upon that. About five in the evening he tooke this ſequent decoction with the ſequent portion of powder.

item.hi: Coq. in. S. q. Aq. Simp.
Ad. Syr. D. Hyſſop. unc. ſs.

div.p: This Evening too the Cataplaſme was taken away, and the ſtipticke Emplaſter applyed.

The ſecond day of the Diſeaſe, or the tenth day of Iuly at ſtaven in the morning we met againe, that night hee had reſted well, the pulſe was a little quicker, the Vrine
bloudy, with a Sediment of grumous or clotted bloud. The wound we ſaw well diſpoſed, and the Patient complained not of any dolor, the wound was mundified with Wine, and two of the ſutures being taken away, and the Balme inſtilled, the Emplaſter was laid on againe. This day too he dranke of the broth of a Capon, wherein theſe following h • arbes were boyled:

item.hi: Cons. Scabios. Melis. Ana. unc. 1. ſs.

div.p: About five a Clocke in the after noone a binding up againe was ordered after the manner aforeſaid, and being ſomewhat coſtive, a ſuppoſitory was adminiſtred, but without effect. Towards night he tooke another draught of the former decoction with the powder.

The third day of the Diſeaſe, and the eleventh of Iuly at ſeaven in the morning the wound was bound up againe after the manner aforeſaid, two ſutures more being taken away. This night he had ſlept but a little, for almoſt all the whole day before he had ſlept ſoundly. His Vrine was yet bloudy, his Pulſe ſomewhat remiſſe and commendable enough, yet felt he a kind of tenſion with dolor in the left Hypochondrium, and having had an Enema infuſed of the decoction of Barley made up with Caſſia and Sugar, but felt not afterwards any evacuation, the ſequent was preſcribed, that the more ſuccesfully the portion of clotted bloud might be diſſolved; for Valeriol. in Obſ. will have Savory to doe very much herein.

item.hi: Sem. Lini. Fenegr. Fenicul. Ana. D. 1. ſs.
Coq. in S. Q. Aq. S. ℞. Colat. Lib. 1.

div.p: The effect hereof was very commendable: for a great deals of excrement we ſaw dyed with a kind of blackneſſe. Alſo that troubleſome Tenſion was eaſed, being annoynted at that time with the oyles of Molleine and Dill. At five a clocke after the accuſtomed manner, all things were adminiſtred in the binding up of the wound.

The fourth day of the Diſeaſe and the twelfth of the moneth, the ſame courſe was obſerved in the mundification and deligation. He had ſlept well, his veine yet was ſomewhat red, his pulſe a little fainter: in Pullet broth the ſequent herbs were boyled.
His backe alſo was annoynted with Vng. Roſaceum. Nor was there any thing altered in that after noones deligation.

The fifth day of the Diſeaſe, and the thirteenth of the moneth, at ſeven in the morning we went againe to viſit our Patient, indeed he had then but an ill nights reſt, yet was there not any feebling of his ſtrength, and his Pulſe 'twas laudable. The Vrine we ſaw of a gold colour, with a white Sediment, but very much and thicke: the Pus of the wound appeared good, and the coſtivenes was helpt
with the uſe of Clyſter the wound as before was lookt unto, and which was done too in the after-noone.

The ſixth day of the Diſeaſe, and the foureteenth of the moneth in the morning, the wound was mundified with Wine, impregnated with Myrrhe and Aloes, and the deligation ordered after the uſuall way. His tongue being ſomewhat dryer was humected with Mel Roſatum, but his necke was annoynted outwardly with the oyle of ſweet Almonds. And the ſame was obſerved and performed in the evening.

The ſeventh day of the Diſeaſe, and the fifteenth of the moneth he had a quiet night of it, his Pulſe ſtrong enough and now ſeemed to bee ſafe, the wound after the uſuall manner was bound up, and the ſame done againe in the after-noone.

The eighth day of the Diſeaſe, and the ſixteenth of the moneth there was no alteration made. Hee dranke this day ſome ſmall portion of Rhubarbe infuſed Cum Syr. Dyſent Dorner, which gave him but one ſtoole. All the other dayes after untill the foureteenth of the Diſeaſe, the ſame manner of deligation and mundification was obſerved, but that the Balſame was not ſo often uſed, leaſt the wound might come ſooner to conſolidation than was fitting, and from the Myrrhed wine alſo we did abſtaine.

The things that were done afterwards when theſe daies were ended are but ſlight, and not worth the rehearſall. Howbeit the Ordinance of his diet was held to bee exact. For though nature be accuſtomed to groſſer meates, yet by reaſon of the Ventricle that was hurt alteration of diet for a time was needfully to bee appointed. That negotiaon by reaſon of crudity might not bee troubleſome to the wound and the Patient to himſelf • . And hence had hee untill the foureteenth day his drinke given him moderately warme.

And ſo by the grace and clemency of the Omnipotent Jehova, and ſupreame Director, and with the ſingular induſtry and dexterity of the Phyſitians and Chyrurgion, our Ruſticke Swallow-knife was reſtored to very good
health, who now complaines not any thing of any dolors of the Ventricle, but being returned to his accuſtomed dyet and ordinary calling, with us gives thankes to the immortall God. To him therefore bee the glory, praiſe, and honour for ever and ever, Amen.

div.head: Poſition 8. As the ſuddaine cloſing of the wound of the Ventricle, ſo too the excretion of clotted bloud by Vrine is to bee reckoned for a benefit of a provident nature.
div.p:
THe admirable efficacy of nature in the profligation and curation of Diſeaſes can with no commendations be ſufficiently ſet forth, and with no ſharpeneſſe of underſtanding enough ſearcht into and unfolded: for even thoſe things, which we ſee before our eyes are accounted as impoſſible, nature alone doth execute and bring to a wiſhed end. Shee it is that excites the lurking ſparkes of an inbred heate, and fights againſt the violence of Diſeaſes, and uſually overcomes them. She it is that even to amazement often times expells a noxious humour by the ſecret pores, and puts it far from our bodies. Whence not leſſe prettily than truely and learnedly is nature by Baricellus entitled The Captaine,Lib. 2. De Hydronosnat. c. 34. and the Prefect defending the body from the Ambuſhes and Aſſaults of a Diſeaſe, for however a diſeaſe the bitter enemy of health may bandy up a force of various Symptomes and Accidents, whereby in a Hoſtile manner to aſſault the parts of the body; yet Nature like a iealous Defendor endevoureth to preſerve it, and the powers thereof from the incurſions of ſymptomes, and inſidiations of the Affects, and with all her might intentively, whereby ſhe may have the victory. Doth not Nature by the excitation of internall heate ſuccou • ing the diſeaſe diſcuſſe, and conſume whatſoever might hinder
their Sence and voluntary motion, that whom not the laborious hand of the Curer, not the acute induſtry of Phyſitians, nor the diverſe kinds of medicaments have beene able to reſtore, ſhe alone hath vindicated from the violence of death and the diſeaſe? How often are the Apoplectickes, who were thought preſently to give up the Ghoſt, by the benefit of nature recollecting her powers to the depulſion of what was offenſiue, healed and revive? And whence by Law it was provided, that not theſe that had the charge of the enterments, or the Bearers ſhould preſently Coffin up thoſe whom they tooke for dead, ſince in them eſpecially if over-whelmed with the Apoplex, Epilepſie, or ſuffocation of the Mother, the ſoule may often lurke, which being excited, endues the body againe with ſpirit and life. If ſuch bodies likewiſe doe not preſently diſſolve with rottenneſſe and corruption, they ſhall not be delivered up for buriall till after the courſe of ſeventy two houres expired, wherein it happens that the humours are at a ſtay and will not be moved, becauſe the Moone in that time will have run through one ſigne of the Zodiacke, by the vertue whereof, the docurſe of the humours is in bodies perfected.

Amatus Luſitanus recites a ſtory worth the abſervation; A Girle ſaith he of Ferrarie, Lemn. Lib. 2 Pe occult. Nat. Mar c. 3. Foreſt Lib. 10 Obſ. 79 Il hol. ſee alſo Aviceu • . 1 l. Tr 5. c 12. Cent. 4. Curat. 2. ſtricken with the Apoplex, was of all the Phyſitians held for dead, but the mother loving her exceedingly, did not ſo eaſily allow that ſhe ſhould bee buried, and the more, becauſe ſhe had underſtood of others, that thoſe that are ſuddenly ſnatcht away with grievous Diſeaſes, and reckoned for dead, ſhould not ſo eaſily and on a ſuddaine be committed to the Clergy. The Mother therefore though all ſaid nay, made the Girle to bee kept with her for three dayes, and the third day the Girle revived, as if ſhee had beene riſen from the Grave. How doe women that are ſuffocated with the mother, and preſently reckoned for dead, by the ſtrength of nature alone, as it were take life againe, as witneſſeth the Volumes of Phyſitians? The Hiſtory of that Matron of Collein is notable, whoſe Houſe is there at this day to bee ſeene in the New
Market, ſhe whother by ſtrangulation of the Mother, or as others will, taken ſuddenly away with the Plague, is buried for dead. But the Bearers they knew of a little Ring that was left upon ber fingers, wherefore the next night after goe ſecretly to the Grave, dig up ye Coffin and open it, what comes of it? ſhe that was buried raiſeth up her ſelfe and takes the Bearers Lanthorne, that being ſtruck with feare were flying away, and makes haſt home to her Huſbands houſe, by whom after wards being knowne, and a good ordinance of dyet uſed, ſhe recovered and bare three Sonnes, whom ſhe brought up to beare Rule in the Eccleſiaſticall Miniſtery, as Cameratius hath it.Cerot. 7. Obſ 46. How often are many that have beene a long time lame, feebled and ſhrunke up, to wit, being ſtrucks with anger, feare, or ſore affrighted with the danger of fire, ſuddainely reſtored unto very good health, as examples witneſſe in Valeriola. Lib. 2. Obſerv. Medic. obſ. 4. & p. 164. Donat. Lib. 7. Hiſt. Med. Mirab. 9. Zacut. Lib 1. De med. Princip. Hiſt. p. 255. Schenk and others. Secondly nature alſo uſually by waies altogether abſtruſe, and the ſecret pores wonderfully expells forth of the body a peccant humour in the body, and lying in waite for life, that, that which before had mockt the induſtry of the Phyſitian, ſhould by Nature afterward alone be overcome and driven away. She opens what are ſhut, no was it were uſeleſſe deſtinates them for uſe. Cl. Arniſaeus, as witneſſeth Cl. Horſtius, Epiſtol. Med. p. 459. obſerved in a young thiefe that was diſſected, the Anaſtomoſis or coniunction of the Vena cava & Arteria venoſa, as alſo of the Vena canalis, from the great Artery to the Vena Arterioſa, to be no more open than in an Infant new borne. How likewiſe the obliterated Veſſells in the diſeaſed of the Dropſie,Vide Foreſt. e. 19. Obſ. 33. Beniv. c. 42 Donat. Lib. 4. c. 21 Sennert. Lib. 3. pract c. de Hydrop. may againe bee opened for the ſafety of the ſicke by the benefit of nature alone, and the ſerous matter thence evacuated, practice doth teach: But what's to bee ſaid of the motion and pregreſſe of vitious humours, by wayes never enough to be perceived? Of matter evacuated by Vrine from the Thorax among infinite examples Regiſtred in Authors, that may be teſtified, which the famous
Sennertus hath noted as well in Lib. 2. Pract. p 2. c. 11. as in other places of a certaine young Student, who in the yeare one thouſand ſixe hundred twenty three, received a wound in and through his Breaſt by a narrow bladed Sword, on the right ſide about the third rib, neere the Arme-pit, and going forth at the Region nigh the Backe bone, ſo that no doubt was made but that the Lungs were hurt, ſince the ſpirit too with a great found iſſued at the wound, and a very great aboundance of blood was effuſed &c. This man at firſt deiected ſome bloud by ſtoole, but the matter of bloud, which was gathered together betwirt the Muſcles and the skin in great aboundance and together had poſſeſſed the neck, and cauſed there a manifeſt humour without any coughing, was evacuated by retching, eiecting ſpittle white enough and plentifull. Who will not ſay that beere the ſecret naturall Conflux of Hippocrates takes place?
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Who will not wonder at the imperſcrutable motions and paſſages of nature.

But ſince even this wounded man was not onely as hee wiſhed, by the grace of God at ſhort time cured, but alſo at this very houre is well, and from that time unto this hath not felt any trouble in his reſpiration, nor in his other actions Vitall, Animall or naturall, and for thirteene yeares lived ſafe and ſound in a much deſired Wedlocke, albeit in moſt painefull practice and other publike occupations, for theſe together hee hangs up his vowed memoriall-Tables unto the moſt Good and Great God his onely preſerver, and gives him devout thankes for ſo great benefits hitherto underſervedly beſtowed upon him. Moreover hee gives and ſo long as life remaines, will ever give continuall thankes to his moſt diligent Phyſitian, the • amous Sennertus his quondam Maſter, for his faithfull care, praying for his healthy old age, and the continuance of his ſtrength and all proſperity. But thou O God protect under the ſhadow of thy wings too, ever to come the ſame man before wounded, and ſtoutly defend him againſt the envy and calumny of the wicked, and at laſt out of the moſt troubleſome
race of this perfidious age, vouchſafe to call him away into the heavenly Academy.

Theſe the benefits of Nature providently and exceedingly well working, our Ruſticke alſo hath the experience of, partly in that moſt ſuddaine occluſion of the wound of the Ventricle, after extraction of the knife, and partly in the evacuation of concreted bloud by Vrine. That the internall conſtitution of the Ventricle was able to promote, being more plaited and ſtored with many foldes, which if dilated doe forth-with againe goe together; this the inexplicable goodneſſe of nature, after the Divine mercies. For I pray, what moleſtation, what concourſe of Symptomes would have riſen if the bloud had remained without the Veſſells? certainely it had rotted and cauſed a feaveriſh heats. But if you ſhall enquire the waies by which the bloud might bee carried • owne to the Raines, and by the Vrine evacuated, you'l ſcarce find them plaine, it ſuffireth that they are knowne to nature, whoſe motion if the Phyſitian diligently obſerve, hee will bee able eaſily to imitate her. The whole body is indeed confluxible and perſpirable; confluxion is one, perſpiration is one, all parts are conſenting, as witneſſeth Galen. Lib. 6. Epidem. Lib. 3. De natur. Facult. &c. Hence Nature hath evacuated matter contained in the top of the Thigh by the mouth, in an other as obſerves Horſtius. Lib. 4. Chirurg. Obſ. P. 2. p. 353. ſhee hath forced downe the matter of Tumor about the right knee unto the Ventricle, and by vomit caſt it up againe. Hence as teſtifieth Hildan Cent. 1. Obſ. 81. An abſceſſe about the ſhoulder being too late opened, the humour ſeeking his way downewards by the bottome of the belly, • ath flowed down into the privities, and the Naturall heate being extinct hath begotten a Gangreens, and by and by after a Sphacell or mortification, but of theſe enough.

div.head: Poſition 9. As the great wounds of the parts are not to bee left to a Prognoſticke onely: So neither are ſmall wounds to be diſ-regarded, for of every kind of wounds men may dye, as Hippocrates teacheth, and experience confirmes.
div.p: TWo things there are which the Phyſitian in his practice muſt eſpecially deteſt, to wit Timidity, and Audaciouſneſſe: for it, as Hippocrates de Lege witneſſeth, argues the impotence; this the ignorance of Art but both expoſe the Patient to a more eminent danger; for him whom Nature would have kept up, they thruſt into the Grave. Wherefore in Diſeaſes that are full of danger, the Phyſitian muſt be of a ready Iudgement, his prudence muſt direct the courſe of a dangerous Curation. But in • ighter diſeaſes he muſt ſet apart all over-boldneſſe, that the malady prevaile not againſt hope, and the ſicke-man dye, which as in all other diſeaſes ev • n ſo in wounds muſt very heedfully bee regarded.

Wounds exceedingly mortall, and of all held for incurable, are uſually cured by the ſtrength of nature, & by goodnes of the temperament. Alſo ſlighter wounds and which are almoſt of no moment, have commonly ſound but a mortall iſſue, the wounded ſubſtance of the Braine it ſelfe, and a portion there of being loſt, no man but would ſay that it was to be given up for a deadly wound, yet beyond hope have men ſo wounded bin very well recovered, as witneſſe Valleriol. Lib. 4. Obſ. 10. Lib. 5. Obſ. 9. Lib. 6. Obſ. 4. Hildan. Cont. 4. Obſ. 1, 2, 3. And a Cruce de Vulnerib. Lib. 1. tr. 2. c. 14. and others quoted in Schenk. Lib. 1. Obſ. 40.42. Indeed Amat. Luſitanus. Cent. 3. Cur. 41. in Comm. is of opinion, that with a little portion of the Braine extracted, not onely the Patient almoſt alwaies
dyes, but alſo if it ſo happen that any doe ſcape, that he remaines deafe and dumb &c. that the other is true, infinite examples can teſtifie,
• om. 2. Noſologi diſput. 36. quaeſt. 10. eſpecially ye which Petraeus relates of a Boy wounded in the head, who although hee loſt tos much of the ſubſtance of his braine — yet was hee not onely very well recovered, but alſo there was not any of his Animall actions hurt, and the ſame Boy I ſaw with mine eyes in the yeare 1615. firſt when I ſtudied at Marpurg, he was luſty and very crafty, not onely in his employments, but alſo villanies. Who would beleeve that a man with a ſmall bullet ſhot into his bowells out of a braſſe Trunke could have eſcaped ſafe? which yet we read in Valleriola did thus happen unto one.Lib. 4. obſ. Med. 9. So doubtleſſe where Nature plaies her part well, and the faculties are firme, there's no wound to be reckoned of any danger, according to Galen: but where they are infirme, 10. Meth. Med. or ſome other cauſe alſo ſhall moleſt, nature quickly failes even about a ſlender wound. Now long ſince Hippocrates hath witneſſed as much in his boy Philias, to whom, from but the denundation of the bone in the fore-head, a feaver happened, which the lividneſſe of the bone received, and by and by after death it ſelfe. Some-what not unlike this fell out here at Regiomont: for but ſome few yeares agoe a young Student of an excellent to wardneſſe was by an idle knave wounded to the very bone on the fore-head, nigh the Coronall ſuture, the fourth day he felt the accesſion of a feaver, and with a Prognoſtick given the ſeventh day dyed. The Captaine of a great Ship as witneſſeth Hippocrates, with the Anchor having bruiſed his ſore-finger and the bone of his right hand, an inflamation and Convulſion followed after, and the thirteenth day he dyed.Lib. 7. nat. Hiſt. c. 73. Lib. 3. enarrat. Med. p. 444. Out of Pliny we have it, that Q. Aemilius Lepidus of his great Toe, being quaſhed at the entrance of his bed chamber, gave up the Ghoſt. It is evident out of Valleriol, of Ludovicus Vives that famous man, that of a ſmall wound and altogether deſpicable, received in the palme of his left hand, ſcarce piercing the fleſh next the skin, with a Convulſion that ſuddainely aroſe dyed. The like you may ſee in Hildan.
Cent. 1. Obſ. 21, & 5. Obſ. 2. &c. Poreſt. lib. 6. Obſ. Medic 49.50. Gemm. lib. 1. Coſmocritic. c. 6. Matth. queſt. me • . 27. Sennelt. tr. 6 Pract. p. 371. About ſome foure yeares agoe and more, a Noble-man L. Marſhall of of the field not far from Mount-Royall in Boruſſee in a Duell, had given him from another Nobleman, likewiſe a very ſmall wound in the Abdomem without hurting the Ventricle and inteſtines, but he, before a little halfe houre quite ſpent, preſently gave up the ghoſt. A certaine other Electorall Courtier in ſome brabbles received a ſmall wound in the Legs, but forth-with expired. Such miſchances, alack! doe almoſt every day fall out, but in the explication of their cauſes many ſeem to be at a ſtay: There are thoſe that aſcribe the ſucceſſe of the unlookt for events to the peculiar diſpoſition of the Stars, and that alſo an unlucky iſſue followes after the evill Aſpect of the Planets, but after the benigne Aſpect like wiſe the like effect. But ſince this cauſe is both Vniverſall and very remote, it may eaſily be hindred with thoſe that are more neare, whereas in dying particular cauſes may prevaile. Others with Matth. ſay • hat the cauſe is in the condition & nature of the open Air when from the coldneſſe thereof a wound may eaſily receive alteration, Hippocrates, Lib. 5. Aph. 20. and elſe-where ſaith: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that the cold is a biting enemy unto Vlcers, whereunto Galen. 5. M. Med. 12. ſubſcribes, which in the wounds of the head is not to be thought unreaſonable: for for that cauſe as Paraeus, at Paris the wounds of the head are obſerved to bee more mortall than at Avignon, Lib. 9. Chirur. and on the contrary with us the wounds of the ſhins are ſlighter than with them. For at Paris the aire is cold & moiſt, but at Avignon the heat thereof more intenſe, whereby the humours made liquid flow more downe-wards. For the like cauſe the wounds of the head at Bologna are eſteemed mortall, which at Rome though are very eaſily cured, and on the contrary the ſmall wounds of the Legs are ſcarce curable at Rome, which at Bologna admit an eaſie conſolidation, as witneſſe Bald. Ronſ. d. Scorb. c. 1. vide et Cl. Senn. Tr. 6. Pract. 373. Amat.
Luſitan. Cent. 6. Cur. 100. Thirdly many there are who ſuppoſe we are to caſt one upon nature her ſelf, for ſay they, if her conſtitution be laudable, the naturall Balſame vigorous, all things yet goe well, and even incurable wounds uſually gaine an happy iſſue. But if Nature bee not of that good cheere, the bloud exceedingly corrupt, and nature her ſelfe ſeeme as it were for to diſſolve, there verily even the ſlight and ſuperficiall wound is made mortall. In theſe ſubitaneous chances I may ſay wee muſt have reſpect chiefly to the pasſions of the mind. The aire can doe much, but ſuccesſively, for neither will it cauſe a momentany alteration, nor will the corruption of Nature her ſelfe ſo ſo much as be able to induce, with the concourſe of Symptomes a ſuccesſive deſtruction, but after a ſlight ſtroke or ſmall wound ſcarce have they beene able to infer a ſuddaine death. I altogether conceive▪ that there are three affections of the mind, that cauſe this mortality, to wit, violent anger, exceeding feare, as alſo ſuddaine terrour or affrightment. Which way thoſe three may alter a man otherwiſe in good health, it is ſufficiently manifeſt out of Phyſitians Bookes, and daily experience doth teach as much.

Hildans conceite is not amiſſe,Cent. 1. Obſ. 18. that of all the perturbations of the mind anger is the fierceſt, and a very fruitfull Nother of infinite miſchiefes, becauſe as Galen hath it, by too much exagitating ye humours weakning the naturall heate, convulſion of the Nerves ſtirring up of grievous fits in the body, ſhe doth not onely change the nature of man into a moſt cruell beſtiality as it were, but alſo expoſe the ſame to moſt eminent danger. Indeed Galens opinion is, that no man can dye of anger: but not onely the examples alleadged in Hildan. L c But there are more alſo that evince the contrary, eſpecially if on a man that's too much enraged a wound be inflicted, although it be but ſmall, not becauſe as 'tis commonly ſuppoſed: Er hat im dat Oort des leb • ns getroffen, You have taken life in that place, as if in the body life did walke up and downe, and that if that part where life then reſides he wounded, a man
preſently at that time muſt looſe the ſame, but rather becauſe the h • mours and ſpirits being agitated by anger, and the heat too much faintned, yea by the affluxe of humours uſually extinct, the life muſt bee endangered: for ſo the Phyſitians have obſerved, that on ſuch as were too impetuouſly ſtirred up with an impotent anger, the Apoplex hath fallen, and they ſuddainely have expired, of whom there are many examples that I could reckon up, which within theſe few yeares have fallen out at Regiomontium, but it pleaſeth to reſerve theſe for ſome other Diſcourſe. Truely they chiefly are throughly ſenſible of a diſcommodity, hence who have gotten too hot a temperature of the whole body either by nature or a diſeaſe, for then the naturall heat • may more eaſily be endangered. And what a ſuddaine amazement may doe, it is not unknowne, for this it cauſeth a ſuddaine hoarineſſe, as it is to be ſeene by many in Marcell. Donat. Lab. 1. De Med. Hiſtor. Mir. 2. p. 14. Nicol. Florent. Sueton. in vita Galbae. Hadrian. Iun. Comm. de Coma. c. 10. Petr. Meſſin. Hiſpan. in Sylv. variar. Lection. Scaliger. Exerc. 313. Lenm. lib. 2. de Complex. 1. Schenk. and others, becauſe the heate and ſpirits goe backe to the fountaine of life, and forſake the extremities, whereby cold is brought upon theſe parts, that not onely the heauty of the face is ſpoiled, but alſo young men are made hoary, yea and the wounded brought unto a ſuddaine and ſometimes momentary deſtruction. And to conclude feare conceived in the mind doth preſently exagitate the heart, obnubilate the underſtanding, perturba •• the Animall faculties, and at length ſo vitiate and infect all our actions, that by the malignity thereof the imaginary faculty is diſturbed from its ſtate, the braine enfeebled, and the ſick man not onely in a wonderfull mann • r diſcruciated, as Quercetanus, S. 1. Diae • . Poly-hiſt. cap. 9. but alſo the vitall heat it ſelfe as it were ſuffocated. Wherefore if any one either with anger, fuming, or ſtricken with a ſuddaine terrour and over-much feare, ſhall receive a wound although but ſmall, not without cauſe may the reaſon of his ſuddaine death bee referred unto theſe effects.

div.head: Poſition the 10. and laſt. The uſe both of the Tents and Deligation ordered twice a day, as in this caſe it was, even ſo in other caſes is it exceeding neceſſary.
div.p:
IT is a golden Rule of our Divine Hippocrates where he ſaith: A veterum doctrinâ reſidere, & nova praeter rationem comminiſci, cum per ſe temeratium eſt, tum in faciendo periculoſum. To recede from the Doctrine of the Ancients, and to invent new wayes againſt reaſon is in it ſelfe as temerarious as in doing it is dangerous. For albeit there are many things left for this latter age to find out and amplifie, yet if the ancient things be altered and new induced againſt reaſon not ſo much for verities ſake and utility, as for novelty and poore ſelfe glory, it will ſcarce be able to deſerve excuſe. The old Phyſitians who chiefly placed their endeavours upon Chirurgery, did furniſh the ſame with exceeding great ſtudy, and intermitted nothing that might make for the perfection thereof, notwithſtanding to goe backe from their Decrees is an offence that many neoterickes can not ſatisfie. All other waſes being left. our Patients caſe propounds two at leaſt; one concernes the uſe of Tenis, the other Deligation inſtituted twice a day; both they iudge unneceſſary, yea ſupervacaneous and to bee ſuperſeded for an unprofitable labour. For Caſar Magatus and with him Septalius, whom too doe follow many Chirurgions with very ill ſucceſſe, ſuppoſe, that there is no need of Tents in wounds, nor of deligation to be uſed twice a day, for thinke they Tents moleſt nature by diſtention, compresſion of the part affected, and excitation of dolors. Secondly that they availe nothing, ſince the vertue of the Medicaments without Tents can duely bee carried downe to the part offended. But however
it bee to bee allowed that there is no need of Tents in wounds ſuperficiall, ſtraite and generating, but little Pus, as indeed hereunto conſolidation to bee maturated as much as may bee, nor purpoſely retarded, not leſſe ignorantly then impiouſly perſwaded Fioravanta, and as for that cauſe not long ſince was Theſſalus reprehended by Galen:
• . m. Meth. yet other caſes there are that neceſſarily require the uſe of Tents, becauſe by the operation of Tents the Orifice of the wound is kept open, that thereat the Pus might iſſue. Secondly, that by the benefit of them the vertue of the Medicaments might arrive at all and every part of the wound, eſpecially that from the bottome primarily conſolidation and unition might bee made, leaſt that by the upper part of the wound being cloſed, in the lower part an iſſue for the Pus might not bee afforded, which I have obſerved very often to fall out by the neglect of Tents but to produce examples it would bee hatefull, whereas in many it would eaſily move choller. Briefly with Tagaultius I conceive, that in eight Caſes chiefly Tents are not to be neglected, but uſed.

list.item: 1. When wounds are either to bee enlarged or deterged, or when any thing from the bottome is to bee evacuated.
2. In hollow wounds where the generation of loſt fleſh is needfull.
3. In wounds altered by the aire and ſordid, which need deterſion.
5. In wounds which with Phlegmon or any other Tumor againſt nature doe much moleſt.
6. In thoſe that are made by bitings, for every biting almoſt,Lib. 5. as Celſus his opinion is, hath a kind of a poyſon which is alwaies to be evacuated.
7. In thoſe that muſt be handled about the bones.

8 Thoſe that now by oldneſſe have degenerated into V • cers full of deflurions. Theſe caſes if the Chirurgian ſhall not well conſider, and by neglect of Tents too much truſt and attribute onely to his Emplaſter, let him take
heed that he hath not experience of the like ſad ſucceſſes,Cent. 4. Obſ. 76. ſuch as Hildan commemorates. Read Aquapend. part. 2. Chirurg. Lib. 2. c. 8. Peccet. Lib. 2. Chirurg. c. 14. Senn. Lib. 5. pract. 4. cap. 9.

div.p:
Secondly neither doe they eſteeme deligation ſo neceſſary, that every day once or even twice the ſame ſhould bee uſed, but ſufficient, that at the firſt the wound bee opened and abſterged onely on the ſixth or ſeventh day, and with new remedies adminiſtred, bound up: for that becauſe with a more frequent deligation the wound with the open aire is altered, the temperament of the part deſtroyed, and that hence is generated a greater plenty of excrements, conglutination hindered, and that inflamation, dolor and the like doe readily follow after. But on the contrary if deligation bee more ſeldome and ſlowly uſed, that the Temperament of the part offended remaineth in its due ſtate, that but little matter of excrements is begotten, that the naturall heate is conſerved in its owne vigor, that all ſymptomes are precautioned, and that the cure of the wound may ſooner and more ſucceſfully bee finiſhed, for the nature of the part helped with externall Balſame of its very owne accord haſteth unto conſolidation and averts the ſymptomes to bee ſeared. Notwithſtanding as theſe may take place in wounds ſuperficiall and but ſhallow Tagaultius ſo adviſing,Lib. 2. Chirurg. p. 207. and that deligation is to bee protracted untill the fourth day, except perhaps ſome violent delor may come thereon, or ſome other troubleſome ſymptome happen: yet in deepe wounds, I hold it to bee unfitting ſo to protract deligation, and againſt reaſon to ſwerue from the Counſells and Decrees of the Ancients. For there's no reaſon that wes ſhould feare an intemperate aire, but eſpecially the cold and moiſt, an enemy to wounds, ſince that may either bee avoyded or even with Art ſo corrected, that no damage can bee thence expected, if by the helpe either of fire or ſome thing elſe the aire bee diſpoſed unto a fit temperateneſſe, which being done, the naturall beat
of the parts affected, whereon I willingly confeſſe turnes the hinge of all the Cure, is conſerved in its due ſtate, no alteration of the Temperament of the part followes after, nor will there bee a more plentifull heaping of excrements, then according to the nature of the wound. But theſe are two-fold, as witneſſeth Galen, 3. M. M. 4. thin and thicke, and they not alwaies ſo diſpoſed that by vapour they might bee diſgeſted and vaniſh into aire; indeed theſe may bee in wounds and cannot bee removed and abſterged but by the hand of the Phyſitian. What I pray will bee more neceſſary than continually to eaſe nature of that burthen, ſince theſe excrements and ſuperfluities remaining, various and grievous ſymptomes may ariſe. But for other cauſes alſo a daily deligation in deepe wounds eſpecially will bee neceſſary. That,
Firſt indeed the Chirurgion well looke unto the ſtate of the part, and of the wound it ſelfe, and that hee know the ſame, ſince wounds eſpecially at unawares get that diſpoſition, that either their fleſh may luxuriate, or wormes therein be generated, or that ſomething elſe come on it.
Secondly alſo, that hee fit the Remedies to the ſtate and condition of the part and wound, for their conſtitution greatly requires that ſome Medicaments be dry, ſome moiſt, for neither during the whole time of the Curation will one Remedy be able to ſuffice.
Thirdly, that by daily deligation cleannes alſo may bee procured, which Hippocrates advertiſeth to bee heeded, that the fouleneſſe of the bandages and clouts moleſt not the Patient.
Fourthly, becauſe Pus beeing daily ſo evacuated, even nature alone haſteth to its Conſolidation: for as ſometimes ſhee alone doth accompliſh this, ſo is ſhe not able likewiſe to evacuate that.

To conclude, experience confirmes that by deligation often uſed if need were, the thread of the Curation is more eaſily and ſuccesfully woven out. And which the Hiſtory of
our Ruſticke Swallow-knife can atteſt: for neither onely was the uſe of Tents ſo exceedingly profitable as it was needfull; but alſo deligation repeated twice a day was with exceeding great profit ſo ordered, and with happy ſucceſſe, and the Conſolidation of the wound diſpatcht as one would wiſh.

But ſince the moſt Clement Jehova, and heavenly Arch-Phyſitian had by his fatherly grace the chiefe doing in this whole worke, to himſelfe deſervedly muſt the thankes be given, and He onely to be implored, that hereafter alſo by his gracious preſence he would vouchſafe to bee preſent and Preſident to all our actions. Let his Name bee bleſſed for ever and ever.

div.head: A Treatiſe of the poſſibility of this Cure.
Cap. 1.
div.p:
IN ſo Noble a Myſtery to beget things new from the intemperatures of Fancy, and idle raptures of conceit, built on Vaine glory without the ſinewes of reaſon and experience to ſtrengthen ſuch Relations that they may carry their owne weight through the difficulties of envy and perverſe opinion, were to heape the burthen of many evills upon my ſelfe. Firſt the generall ſuffrage of
the Iudicious, who muſt proclaime ſuch a raſh undertaker, conſcious of ſelfe affection; a vanity which ſo blemiſheth the man ſhould live in us, that it makes us but ſhadowes of what we repreſent. Secondly, a curſe from the ſubiect of this Art (which is man) of whoſe extremities and ſufferings ſuch erronious Traditions muſt be guilty, if any ſhould bee ſo infected with them as to doe hurt by them. Thirdly, the ſeducing of weake Practitioners, and poyſoning their Studies with ſuch falſe Tenets, even in their foundation of growth and infamy in ſuch imployments, on the ſucceſſe of whoſe beginnings, is partly built thoſe perfections their aptneſſe and naturall gifts are capable of, for in them they are encouraged, being enflamed with deſire, to confirme that in their knowledge, in which yet they are but imp • rfect, and onely have a ſnatch of: for having not ſeald with boldnes their Actions, (through a faint aſſurance of what they know) ſuch puzzles muſt needs affright them, with unneceſſary doubts, in all their executions: untill experience, bred up by tedious and ſevere obſervations living in the age of many yeares, and gray haires ſhould returne the infamy into my Grave, that when my Spirit hath met with peace and reſt, my aſhes ſhould bee rak't up in diſdaine by Poſterity, to repeate me with reproach and diſhonour, and this would be the fourth worſt and laſt miſchiefe I ſhould purchaſe to that remnant of me the earth muſt inherit.
Next although ancient Authors have mentioned ſuch wounds mortall, yet Galen ſuſpected a better ſucceſſe, if attempted.
Theſe times have confirmed ſome, and confuted many other able Writers in their Opinions concerning this matter.
We are not to conclude that Authenticke, although for many Ages accepted ſo, which experience the Mother of all confirmation denies.

The common allowance of the venime of Gun-powder met with no obſtacle from the Learned (and for much time) untill worthy Maſter Gale refuted that errour, although
the compoſition in it ſelfe carrieth no ſuch evill: which muſt be well knowne to the famous Phyſitians of thoſe dayes, but in the firſt inuention of
• unus, and thoſe violent materialls appertaining, the diſaſters (without a knowne remedy) happening, and the Chyrurgions of thoſe times not conſidering that in ſuch ſolutions there is a large ſeparation of united parts, with a miſerable rending of the muſcles and nerves, through the furious breaking up of the confines of nature, with horrible confuſions, through which evills thronging together intollerable dolours are bred, with inflamations, benummings of ſinowy parts, Fiſtula, nay the violation of all quiet in every member of the body is kindled, as fever, ſincope, convulſions &c. unto which ſymptomes in woundes of the fleſhy parts the ancients were not accuſtomed, but ſtood amazed at their rage and deplorable endings; which in other diviſions by ſharpe ſpeares &c. they were not diſturb'd with onely meeting with calme diſtempers in reſpect of theſe, being not accompanied with ſuch cauſe of accidents, (if they were not in the noble parts and mortall) as alſo ſince to their eye the perforations of Harq •• buz-ſhot, and Lance-punctures, appeared of equall ſhape and danger outwardly.
By theſe examinations and events, they concluded there muſt be a venimous quality in the Gun-powder, by which it wrought ſuch miſchiefes in thoſe parts where their fury hapned.

This opinion the Learned of thoſe ages authorized, encountring no deniall for many yeares, ſuch was the blind reverence thoſe times held towards the authorities of their Grave Writers: A nice vertue (in my iudgement) onely able to bridle an apt Genius, and to ſmother in the duſt of ignorance and oblivion what ripe ſpirits may either adde to illuſtrate, beget to amplifie, or refu •• to make pure the ſubſtance, extents, and impurities of this noble myſtery.

Now may not the Iudgement of the Ancients concerning wounds of the Ventricle worke the ſame effects, to keepe in darkeneſſe ſuch truths by their onely power? holding backe ſuch happy attempts in the like misfortunes,
which perchance the ſtrength of nature (in ſuch neglect) by Fiſtulous cloſings hath labour'd to make manifeſt.

Have not many griefes contrary to expectation (even of the moſt learned) arrived unto happy ſucceſſe in healthfull concluſions? which then pasſing the teſt of a ſerious examination, the errours have beene found to ariſe from the meere cenſure and allowance of ſome learned Phyſitions, without any mention, Hiſtory, or memory of their experience, to affirme ſuch deliveries for ••• truth, on whoſe precepts, and by whoſe example, poſterity hath alſo rear'd to future times their workes, but further and more chiefly to let paſſe this kind of ſearch: when I conſider the infinite mercies of God in ſuch and the like miraculous Recoveries, and how apt and willing nature is, to preſerve the prerogatives of health inviolate from the hurt and invaſion of Diſeaſes, and being wounded with any griefe, how provident ſhe is to keep her ſelfe from greater evills, and laborious to free her fabricke from the preſent affliction, I cannot then ſo much wonder at, as not to beleeve ſuch great workes of nature made able by divine Providence, and asſiſted by Art, as this fore-going Treatiſe maketh mention of, and experience witneſſeth.

div.head: Cap. 2. Wherein ſome things of notable regard are diſcourſt of very pertinent to this matter, with a neceſſary digreſſion.
div.p:
AMongſt many conſiderations in theſe Caſes, the diligent and expert hand of the skilfull Phyſition (in whoſe knowledge lives that depth is required in dangerous cauſes) is to bee provided, to direct the will and power of nature to benevolent uſes, and to let her hurtfull and unneceſſary promptneſſe, otherwiſe in her
owne bounty ſhe would deſtroy the good intended, as in many deſperate ſolutions (through want of knowledge in the Phyſitian) ſhee doth, ſince the heaping of ſo many fluxions together, is but a ſuddaine and aboundant freedome in nature to ſend all aides thither, to redeeme the diſtreſt member or part to a naturall quiet and proportion, which concourſe of humours are converted to greater burthenings and oppresſions, for it would bee vaine to thinke malignity of humours lurking in the body are altogether the immediate and ſole cauſes of thoſe bad ſymptomes, are frequent with profound and perillous ſolutions, ſince they are of different natures, ſome begotten from actuall emptyings, and ſome proceeding from naturall repletions and accidentall rottennes: neither doe I condemne that opinion, ſince the ſharpeneſſe of ſome inflamations farre exceed others, which muſt proceed from a violent malignity of humours in the bloud,Note. which being thruſt out of the bowells of conſerving heat alter into Pus, and beget the ſouler putrifaction, for it is a notable ſigne, that if after a digeſtive alteration of thoſe heapings paine and induration continue,A neceſſary digreſſion. that there is a bad conſtitution to be handled, and therefore the greater evacuations to bee preſumed neceſſary. (I will a little digreſſe) Since thereby a laudable pulling backe from the member afflicted, is brought to paſſe by bleeding, and purifying of the bloud by purgings is effected, for in all the duties and intentions of healing, the aboundance and bad qualities of bloud is very carefully to be reſpected and hindred, for without ſuch effectuall corrections, there will bee but vile healing of wounds of ſmall danger, and none produced in diviſions of perill and profundity, becauſe bloud is the Author of healing being directed and asſiſted, by and with the skill, method and medicine of 〈◊〉 expert Phyſitians, I meane in parts (to bee united) and derived from bloud; and yet with great care muſt this be done, ſince ſome bodies cannot to the precepts of Phyſicke forſake their ordinary diet, or bee ſtrictly kept and handled as the Rules of Art would enforce without perill, as in its proper Chapter ſhall bee ſhowne. Thus
much briefly, touching the excellency of nature in will and power, the Art and skill of the Phyſitian, to bring ſuch wounds within the liſts of posſibility and Cure, in guiding that Will and Power, and the necesſities of generall and particular evacuations urged from the cauſe, appearing, or threatned.

div.head: Chap. 3. Wherein is toucht ſome other conſiderations concerning this matter.
div.p: OVr next conſideration muſt reflect upon the part, which we muſt examine, to know if it be ſo neceſſary to life, as not totally in ſome functions, or a portion of their functions, to be ſpared without diſſolving of the whole frame, and here indeed are ſome queſtions concerning the preſent occaſion to bee answered.

Some may obiect, that in ſuch wounds there muſt be a ruine of nutrimentall matter and ſubſtance partly produced through the viſible griefe of what was and ſhould bee united, and partly by deprivation of the vertue & faculties of the ſtomacke, ſince parts of groſſer compoſition, and much leſſe uſe to life, ſuffer under ſuch and the like cauſes of the ſame effects.

Stronger reaſons being added to the former, ſince in this Treatiſe we muſt conſider that the Inciſion was made by the hand of the expert Phyſition, with large premediations, where, when, and how to bring his attempts to good event, the Patient having much time before, drunke a balſamicke Oyle, thereby to infuſe a quality of healing into the part, and to enable the member againſt this ſuffering, which in other wounds accidentally given we cannot alledge. Theſe cauſes and helpes, to encourage
us to proceed and ſtrengthen our hopes, and that ſuch balſamick • Oyles and medicines would in time of the wound (being adminiſtred) enlarge fever through diſturbance, and their owne power in heate, by provoking vomits not eaſily, by an able and unhurt ſtomacke to be digeſted, but by adding its owne flame to that is kindled in the veines by the griefe, • ive a ſecond and more dangerous fire unto the evill. To this may be replyed.

div.head: Cap. 4. Wherein is gathered part of a full Anſwer to the Objects in the former, with ſome pertinent additions.
div.p: THough the duties of the Ventricle bee altogether neceſſary to maintaine life,Nota. and ſtrength by the elimentall fuell, yet ſuch a quantity may keepe the fire of life yet glowing, and for much time, although the ſtrength decay in ſome meaſure, or bee largely exhauſted by ſuch wants of ſupply.

To aſſure this, the heate of the ſtomacke by which the digeſtion is wrought, both actually and potentially in the firſt alteration is derived from the Heart, Liver, Arteries Veines, &c. and Muſcles of the abdomen, as from the Fountaines, Channel's and ſeates of all heat and ſpiri •• , by whoſe fire that excellent change of what we receive is potentially perfected, and actually by the Omentum and Muſcles of the belly keeping the Ventricle warme, and defending it from the outward oppresſions of cold.

Now the ſtomack being hurt by ſolution of ioynd parts, is not ſo aboundantly deprived of this heate, being not in it ſelfe (or but a ſmall portion of it) as to beget a generall diſſolving of nature, but onely depraved, and weakned, and the bloud may bee fed by nutriment received into it,
(though afflicted) and altered to laudable Chyle, ſufficient to keepe the vitall heat, and naturall compoſitions from extinction, though not ſo plentifully to nouriſh them.

Next we may further conclude an ability in nature, concerning this matter, ſince many Hiſtories mention, and have regiſtred for Poſterity, that nature (in the prolonging of life) hath bin by more ſtrange and loſſe meanes fed and nouriſht. Next, that although in the digeſtive duty by the excelling there is not ſuch a totall and perfect alteration ance aſweet change of our nutriment to enfeebled bodies muſt needs bee, in regard weake nature ſuddenly periſh under corrupt and vitious alterations, and all this to be eared in reſpect of the want of power and heat.

Yet we may not ſuſpect, but there will be a diviſion of the moſt ſubtile parts of the nouriſhment we receive from the more groſſe,Nota. though not a totall mutation. To enfeebled bodies a ſmall quantity better nouriſhes, then fulneſſe to oppresſion, whereby the vitall vigor yet quickning, the naturall dutyes may have a congruable portion (ſutable to its ſtrongth) of nutriment, to fume into odoriferous Iuce, fit and pure to refreſh the body.

Moreover, although there ſhould not bee that excellent converſion of it, yet the coadiution of parts whither it be drawne and ſent, would asſiſt to perfect it to their owne uſes, as the Liver, ſmall Guts, meſeraickes and veines, may altoran imperfect Chyle or matter ſlited for ſuch change, into the likeneſſe and neareneſſe of bloud, ſufficient to ſuſtaine life untill ſuch wounds be conglutinate, as from an inſected Liver, every member ſucketh an imperfect matter, and yet without any great heate for much time. But how neceſſary enfeebling by ſpare dyet is in all perillous wounds, is not to bee diſpatcht, unleſſe a continued order of food deny.

div.head: Cap. 5. In which is the Anſwer to the Objections fully explicated.
div.p: NExt, for what may be obiected out of this treatiſe, thus much is granted, concerning the place of the wound, that it muſt bee in receipt of it like or neere this inciſion, for if other parts ſhould alſo he perforate that carry in themſelves a perill of death, it would bee ſottiſhneſſe to deny the concluſions, or to preſume or hope by any reaſons, that carry not in them the weight and truth of the cauſe.

By the Balſamicke Oyles imbibed I doe not conclude it ſo expedient,Nota. but that the Ture might have beene effected without it, and rather Iudge it a conceit put in for varietie, and bred from imagination of what it would bring to paſſe, then on necesſity attempted.

My reaſons are, if I would infuſe a quality into a member ſo excellent and nice as the ſt • nacke is,Nota. it muſt not be by any thing, which it or other parts may carry a loathing towards, there muſt bee that ſweet and pleaſant congruity, as there is betwixt fleſh of good and pure Iuice, and the conſtitutions of our bodies, that it may bee received and altered, next it muſt have affinity with the part in its owne complexion, as fleſh hath with blond, of which it is made, for what is not ſo muſt beget diſquiet, and from that a loathing.
But how Oyle and Balſamicke Medicines either by Art preſcrib'd, or Nature produc'd, faile in all ſuch needfull agreements with our bodies Ineed not here urge.

Next there muſt be time admitied, for to imbibe a quality,Nota. is to alter a member in vertues, or to adde or abate ability, as the matter requireth. To give unto it ſelfe a
power to thruſt forth ſuperfluities, but in this occaſion it may bee preſumed to render nature a heate gratefull in digeſtion even in the member it ſelfe contained, as in other parts, whereby it may bee made able to root out what is begotten, and defend it from other bad ſymptomes threatned, together with an aptneſſe to abſterge in corne and glew together theſe are the intents of ſuch infuſion of qualities and theſe all differ in their operations, a • d therefore in their ſubſtances; and to adde unto the compoſition of the ſtomacke more heate then Nature beſtowes upon it, or allowes uſefull and convenient, would enflame it, a temper improper either to cleanſe, digeſt, or ſodder by as Weckernus witneſſeth,Lib 4. Pr • ct General. but if it bee replyed that ſuch vertues are not to be infuſed, by giving the qualities of ſuch intentions, as a quicke and ſharpe effect to mandifie a ſoft and dry heate to incarne, or a dull and cold power to roduce a Sicatrice (which were ridiculous to imagine) but by a benevolent vigor to asſiſt Nature in her Will to further theſe Workes, ſince the other confuſions muſt needs vexe the noble parts, becauſe they muſt be wrought by different meanes, as Wickerus &c. when he diſputes how diſtant in vertues nature and ſubſtance,4 • . Chaps. Pract. Gen remedy that ſhall beget quitture, glew together and make eſcharre are, and to diſturbe with ſo many differences the ſtomacke which was to ſuffer, it cannot be imagined needfull, but that it rather might give it nauſeous then gratefull temper.

And why then ſhould we ſhrinke from the benefits of nature, or doubt her worke, ſince without ſuch ſuſpitious applications, ſhe hath brought to paſſe greater wonders then thoſe which in her firſt Creation ſhee was endued with power to performe. Moreover we know the Balſamicke Oyles have all ſuch vertues, for they clenſe by a ſharpe and ſubtill force, and incarne by a groſſer and ſoſter heate effecting the intent of Siccatrice, by hindring moiſture or the generation of it, therefore by the former obiections, and reaſons concluded hurtfull, as aſſuredly it is.

But as ſome have thought, Balſame hath an emplaſtick body, yet it carries not that body with it in the infuſion of qualities, becauſe of the alteration of it in the ſtomacke, from all likeneſſe it poſſeſſed in its owne figure, neither is that body ſo neceſſary and allowable to infuſe qualities, but a more ſubtill and thin rather to be choſen.

In which conſideration I muſt ever applaud the wound drinkes now in practice, w • ich may bee ſo ordered as to returne a delight in nature to receive them,Maſter Clovves Workes abounds both vvith excellent remedies of this nature. and may be ſo fitted, as to conſort with an eſpeciall aliment—and ſo to be by nature accepted: moreover there muſt bee a difference betwixt things in action and things acted, becauſe Medicaments in their power effect moſt commendably when diſeaſes are extant and in force in the body, not to diſcharge future, (I meane ſuch as are not threatned in the growing defects and ſuperfluities of nature) of which ſort wounds ant their ſymptomes as they reſt ſimply in themſelves, cannot be reckoned, but (may I confeſſe) partake worſe qualities by evill and vitious heapings and conſtitution, which may bee leſſened & curbed in by the skilfull Artiſt, and yet be no argument to feare what doth not appeare, thereby to move the pouring in of many ill reliſht medicaments, with intent, to let what may bee, yet doth ſhew it ſelfe but to ſuſpition onely; or to infuſe what it is naturally poſſeſt of, or to hinder what in its owne ſtrength it labours to doe: and that moſt effectually, excelling the hand of Art in our beſt proviſions.

div.head: Cap. 6. More able Reaſons in briefe collected, witneſſing the Cure of theſe wounds.
div.p:
FUrther to anſwer this posſibility of Cure wee are to conſider, whether the part be the very ſeat of life, as the heart and liver: or ſo neceſſary to life as the Gullet, Wind-pipe, Lungs, ſpleene, gall, kidnies, &c. or ſo violent in their
accidents, with their necesſity of being whole and perfect in the ſervice of noble parts, ſince that they beget furious accidents that aſſault the whole body, as the nervous part of the ſtomacke, Diaphragma, braine, eſpeciall medall &c. or ſo unfitted with the matter of unition as ye ſmall Guts, upper part of the Bladder &c. Beſides in their duties they cannot be ſpared, or whither the remedies may arrive, and remaine to the comfort of the ſufferer and receiver, and not be denyed by the naturall expulſion of the part, or ſunke from the place divided, by reaſon of a large capacity b • neath.

All which conſiderations in the wounds of the bottome of the ſtomacke returne us a hope, ſince it is not the Throne of life, as the Heart, Liver, &c. nor ſo abſolutely neceſſary (in regard of its office to Nature) as the Gullet and Trachea arteriato be unhurt, as Lungs, Spleene, Gall and Kidnies &c.

The firſt utterly denying the receipt of nutriment, the Lungs and Wind-pipe, reſpiration and refrigeration of the Heart, the Spleene, Gall, Kidnies, &c. being the puryfiers of the bloud, not onely in their owne ſubſtance, but alſo in their duties failing muſt be mortall, as conſequently in reſpect of the fordid matter thither ſuckt and ſent, would deny knitting together, neither in the ſymptomes muſt follow, as in the nervous part of the ſtomacke, braine, S • ptum tranſuerſum, which hath affinity and derivation from the Periton. pleura & pericard. or ſpinall marrow &c. which by condulſion would rend wounds in themſelves as the Midriffe, and upper part of the ventricle, or by domittings, paralyſis, Fever, generall contraction of the nerves, paines &c. as in all, (being the Originall of nerves and parts compact of them) bring the ſufferer to death neither in the ſubſtance unfit to conglutinate, as in the ſmall guts, bladder &c. the bottome of the ventricle being paniculous and fleſhy, (for although the ventricle is made of three Coates, in ſome Authors but two) the utmoſt derived of the per • on. the middle membrane fleſhy of its owne proper ſubſtance, the inward nervous, yet the
ſenſible matter of this compoſition is ſo ſpent and enwrapt in fleſhy filaments, that it is not of that exquiſite heate, as the voyce of this kind of making threatens: but to proceed.

Neither in the defect of arriving or naturall expulſion, being the pit and loweſt part, having no capacity (belonging unto its proper making onely) beneath it, and of all members I meane when there is a change of things received) if there be any agreement in the medicine, the ſtomacke is moſt apt to retaine it, of which medicines both of their compoſition, vertue and conſiſtance is diſcourſt in the next Chapters.

div.head: Cap. 7. Of Medecines neceſſary and convenient in the wounds of the Stomacke.
div.p:
IF Experience the mother of ſound reaſon giveth us in knowledge, that Vicers are made more fordid by fatty medicines, which have not in them a cauſbicke quality and quicke power, how much more may wee conclude that parts afflicted by evills are to bee conſidered in their natures, and remedies agreeable to bee adminiſtred, whereby the member ſhall from what is applyed, receive a double refreſhing by a comfortable quality in the medicine, to the member as it lives in its owne proper compoſition, and by a force and ſtrength in the remedy, to extirpe and finiſh the griefe, under which the part languiſheth, thus much is expedient to uſe our meditations in the ſufferings of the extremities that carry in themſelves ability to endure the workes of errour in this caſe; how much more are wee thén to conſider parts of more excellent, delicate, and ſenſible Creation, and ſo notable in the
ſervice of life, yet ſince to treat of all parts in this matter would require a Volumne, brevity being here intended to ſerve the preſent occaſion, with a pa • cell of that, which future time (GOD willing) may beget is thought ſufficient.

div.head: Cap. 8. The Medicines moſt efficient and congruable in wounds of the Stomacke, and why.
div.p: I Have obſerved (intermixt with the reſt) two notable affections of the Stomacke, that it delighteth in heate, and abhorreth to bee refrigerated (I meane being without Diſeaſe) and although heate actually in it ſelf conſumeth moyſture, and that the body would waſt under ſuch heate even to periſhing if the benevolent bumectings were not ſed, yet that the Ventricle in its owne will, derived from its proper being is cheriſht with drynes, though in moyſt bodies given cannot bee denyed, as in old Wines and ſtale liquors is manifeſt, which by heate dryes and doth hinder the begetting of moyſture, in diſpatching ſuperfluities, and procuring unto the noble parts a firmeneſſe and ſtability, ſince humidities onely relaxe and deſtroy thoſe vertues.

Therefore in the wounds of the ſtomacke in what forme ſoever th • y are blended, either in liquid or faſt, the applications muſt bee hot and dry in the firſt and not exceed the ſecond degree, unleſſe there be an excellent coherence with the medicine and the part: a temper in all ſuch medicines and for all wounds moſt commendable.

Next the common thro •• ings in of remedies of doubtfull and earthy ſubſtance is to be avoyded in ſuch perillous diviſions, when the injections are expedient, and the extraction
of Seedes and Flowers, by infuſion or B. M. rather to be choſen then of greene Rootes, and Heathes of groſſe & baſe growth by decoction, the one from odoriferous bodies, pulls an equall excellently mixt heate, and the other corrupt and imperfect, but how uſefull the one, and diſtaſtfull the other is in ſuch Caſes, the Artiſt ſhall know when he comes to the necesſity of them.

It may be acceptable to ſome to ſet here downe what I have uſed in the like extremities, and as the place and ſeaſon afforded proviſions, from which example they may give birth to others, according as the diſtemper ſhall inſt ••• t, as it appeares in the part hurt.

div.p: And although it is Iudg'd needies to convay into profound wounds any infections after a commendable quitture, by which through actuall moyſtening there is a melting inſtability to the member communicated, and that the parts afflicted are hurt and burthened by ſuch unneceſſary loadings, yet, to the finiſhing of ſuch like cures, this may with aboundant profit be uſed, becauſe it doth ſweetly ſtrengthen the naturall heate to haſten digeſtion, to quicken mundification, revive the incarnative power, and withſtand putrefaction, which in all wounds of danger is moſt to be letted.

div.head: Chap. 9. Of what body it is requiſite the Medicine ſhould receive that it may cleave to, if it arrive.
div.p:
ANother conſideration very pertinent offereth it ſelfe in this Diſcourſe, that ſince the topicall adminiſtrations may bee conveyed, but not kept there, it is expedient that they bee incorporated with ſome uſefull Medicine that is of a clammy conſiſtence, whereby when the remedies ſhall arrive they may cleave, and ſo effect your wiſhes in that poynt, I ever thought the Lohoc de pino, or expertum if purged from their groſſe ſubſtances by decoction, and expumation, worthy acceptance, but in ſuch wants I have thus proceeded:
